Dear KENDRA SPANJER:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/20/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation
within 45 calendar days after receipt of the
information. If additional time is required, then the
agency shall inform the foster parent, in writing, of
the basis for the extension and the expected
length of the extension. The total time for the
completion of the investigation may not exceed 90
calendar days without written approval from the
chief administrator or his or her designee.
One of Eight files of open foster homes reviewed contained a special evaluation
report documenting written notification to foster parents of a 45-day extension was
not completed, rather verbal notification was provided.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
One of Seven youth files reviewed (6 foster care, 1 IL) contained an initial service
plan completed outside of the required timeframe (60 days.)
2

CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
• (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the
foster child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in
the child's placement at least once every month.
One of Seven youth files reviewed (6 foster care, 1 IL) did not contain
documentation of a visit with the youth in the youth's placement during the month of
December.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 7/29/2022, CAP Approved 8/23/2022
FOM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
3

One of Seven youth files reviewed (6 foster care, 1 IL) did not contain
documentation related to one FTM.

Interim 7/29/2022, CAP Approved 8/23/2022
F OM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Reports must be submitted utilizing the CWLM functionality in order to document
and track submission and approval dates.
• Ensure accurate documentation as SER: 882 - CWLM/SER indicates 45-day
extension needed and foster parent not notified in writing of the need to extend
the investigation beyond 45 days; however, the extension was not needed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Current licensing rules (400.12326(1)) require that the borrowing agency shall
have a record containing everything required by subsections (1)(a) through (1)(g)
prior to the youth's placement unless subsection (1)(h) or (2) applies or if the
home is a TPP home.
If (1)(h) or (2) do not apply or if the home is not a TPP home, then:
- Compliance with (1)(a,) 1(b,) and (1)(f) can be documented through case
contacts, signed documents, email uploads, etc., whichever method you prefer,
as long as is it entered into the record prior to the placement (unless the
placement is after hours, a tribal home, or a TPP home.)
- Compliance with (1)(c,) (1)(d,) (1)(e) are all documented through the borrowing
agency having access to the record prior to placement
- Compliance (1)(g) can only be documented by the foster parent signing the
foster parent/agency agreement and the agreement being uploaded into the case
record prior to the placement.
If subsection (1)(h) applies, be sure the applicable document is available for
review.
If subsection (2) applies, be sure everything is in the case record as described
above within 3 calendar days of placement.
If the home is a TPP home, CI 20-128 applies as well as the CWLM job aids
specific to TPP homes.
• Licensing rules related to face-to-face visits with youth in their placement are
required every calendar month, despite when the youth initially enter care or
changes placement which differs from policy requirements. Additionally, these
visits can be made by any agency social service worker, as defined by the
licensing rules.
5

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The special evaluation was reviewed, and found to have been completed
thoroughly. Consultation was provided regarding the use of CWLM as well as the
45-day written notification requirements.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP provided was in response to the 7/21/2023 licensing inspection report. That
CAP was approved on 8/8/2023 and addressed two violations, both of which were
related to policy requirements. Both of those citations were repeated this year and
will require additional corrective action planning. One of the remaining three
violations established this year is a repeat of a 2022 violation regarding visiting a
youth in the youth's placement every month and was addressed through a CAP
dated 8/23/22. The two non-repeat violations established this year were related to
special evaluation over 45-days and FTM paperwork.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator identified issues related to lending agencies failing to add
courtesy workers when borrowing foster homes, difficulty obtaining PATP
signatures from AWOL and incarcerated parent as well as parents and caregivers
who are unhappy with the direction the case is taking. Additionally, there have
been difficulties managing paperwork requirements for youth with multiple
placement changes in quick succession.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
Two of the three staff members interviewed reported being very satisfied with their
current job, stating they receive great support and supervision. The third staff
member interviewed reported feeling overwhelmed ad unsupported by her
supervisor. The Director reported during the exit meeting she has met with this
worker and has already set up a meeting with the worker and her supervisor to
further discuss the concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has adequate space and equipment to provide foster care, licensing,
and independent living services. Physical CHRI is stores securely in a locked
cabinet and cross shredding is available on-site.
6

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
